conclusion: To determine when particles A and B meet, we analyze their motion using the v-t graph. The key idea is to find the time when both particles cover the same distance.

The v-t graph shows the velocity of particles A and B over time. Particle A changes velocity from 0 to 2v0 and back to 0. Particle B starts at 0, increases to a maximum less than 2v0, and decreases back to 0.

premise: The area under the velocity-time graph gives the distance covered.
conclusion: The area under the graph for each particle represents the distance they cover.

premise: For Particle A: From t=0 to t=t0, A accelerates from 0 to 2v0. From t=t0 to t=2t0, A decelerates from 2v0 back to 0.
conclusion: Distance covered by A is the area of the triangle: Distance_A = 2v0t0.

premise: For Particle B: From t=0 to t=3t0, B accelerates to a certain velocity and then decelerates back to 0. Given vmax = 4/3v0.
conclusion: Distance covered by B is the area of the trapezoid: Distance_B = 2v0t0.

premise: Both particles cover the same distance 2v0t0.
conclusion: Since they start from the same point and in the same direction, they will meet when they have covered this distance.

premise: The time when they meet is at t = 3t0 because at this time, both have covered the same distance 2v0t0.
conclusion: Particles A and B meet at t = 3t0.
